CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the LAW prohibits discrimination between NORP and NORP Cypriots .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL grants the right to citizens to move freely throughout the island and to reside in any part of it , subject to any restrictions imposed by law and necessary for the purposes of defence or public health or provided as punishment to be passed by a competent court .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL protects the right to property and provides that no deprivation , restriction or limitation of any such right shall be made except where it is imposed by law and is absolutely necessary in the interests of public safety , public health or public morals , town and country planning , the development and use of any property for the promotion of the public benefit or for the protection of the rights of others .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL guarantees the right to equal treatment and nondiscrimination .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL enables a party to any judicial proceedings to raise the question of the constitutionality of any law or decision . However , the provisions of this Article were rendered inoperative following the intercommunal problems in DATE and the procedure for reference under the above provision is no longer applicable . ORG ( Miscellaneous Provisions ) Law CARDINAL/CARDINAL was enacted in order to address a situation of emergency and to set up the necessary judicial machinery for the continued administration of justice . By virtue of this law , the CARDINAL highest courts , that is , ORG and ORG , were merged into CARDINAL , ORG , to which the jurisdiction and powers of the CARDINAL pre - existing courts were transferred . The establishment and operation of the new ORG was held to be in conformity with the LAW on the basis of recognised principles of LAW ( the Attorney - General of the Republic v. PERSON and others , ( DATE ) C.L.R. CARDINAL ) . As the procedure for reference under LAW is no longer applicable in cases other than those of ORG , questions of alleged unconstitutionality are treated as issues of law in the proceedings , subject to revision on appeal in due course , in so far as the lower courts are concerned . All courts when dealing with a case are competent to examine questions of alleged unconstitutionality arising in the case which are material for the determination of any matter at issue .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL vests exclusive jurisdiction in ORG to adjudicate on complaints that administrative decisions are contrary to the LAW or any law , including LAW , or are made in excess of or in abuse of the powers vested in any organ , authority or person .
CARDINAL . Law CARDINAL/CARDINAL ( “ the Law ” ) was enacted according to its preamble to regulate the administration of NORP - Cypriot properties in GPE :

“ Whereas , because of the massive removal of the NORP - Cypriot population as a result of the NORP invasion to the areas occupied by the NORP invasion forces and the prohibition by such forces of the movement of such population within the areas of GPE , properties which consist of movable and immovable property were abandoned ,
And whereas it became essential for the protection of those properties to take immediate measures ,
And whereas the measures taken included the administration of such properties by a special committee which was constituted through administrative arrangements ,
And whereas the regulation by law of the question of the NORP - Cypriot properties in the Republic became necessary ... ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL provides definitions of relevant terms used in the PERSON :

“ ‘ Abnormal situation’ means the situation created as a result of the NORP invasion which continues to exist until ORG , by notification published in ORG , appoints a date for the termination of such situation ;

‘ NORP - Cypriot’ means a NORP - Cypriot who does not have his usual residence in the areas controlled by the LOC and includes a company or other legal person which is controlled by a NORP - Cypriot , as well as by the PERSON ;
‘ NORP - Cypriot property’ includes every property movable or immovable which belongs to a NORP - Cypriot and is situated in the areas under the control of the LOC and includes ORG . ”

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL establishes the post of Custodian of NORP - Cypriot properties who is to administer such property in accordance with the provisions of LAW CARDINAL/CARDINAL and exercise the functions conferred on him by that PERSON during the abnormal situation and until final settlement of this matter is reached .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL stipulates that :

“ Subject to the provisions of this PERSON , the Custodian in administering NORP - Cypriot properties and exercising the functions conferred on him by this PERSON , shall have all the rights and obligations which their NORP - Cypriot owner would have :

Provided that , notwithstanding the amendment to the principal law made by this PERSON , all acts or decisions which have been done or taken by the Custodian , in accordance with the principal law , shall be regarded as having been done or taken lawfully . ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL sets out some specific functions of the Custodian , without prejudice to the generality of LAW . These include :
“ ( a ) to administer every NORP - Cypriot property in accordance with the circumstances of each case and to this end–
( i ) to collect every sum which is due to the beneficiary and to give the necessary receipts ; ...
( ii ) to collect and dispose of the produce of such property in the most beneficial manner for the owner ;
( iii ) to make the necessary payments for the fulfilment of obligations concerning the property under administration ;
( iv ) to arrange for the necessary repairs , improvements , cultivations , plantations or , where necessary , such changes to the property which would be beneficial to the owner ;

( v ) to make arrangements , to enter , terminate or cancel contracts or to undertake obligations or charges concerning each such property and more specifically to lease same at the most favourable terms for the owner ; ...
( vi ) to sell or otherwise dispose of every such movable property which is subject to deterioration or which because of its nature ought to be sold or disposed in the interest of the owner ;
( vii ) generally to do everything which is consequential to or necessary for the administration of NORP - Cypriot properties .

( c ) To accept service of actions , reference or other judicial process concerning NORP - Cypriot property , to represent and bind the owner of any NORP - Cypriot property before any judicial , administrative or other authority in the LOC or anywhere else outside the LOC , to give or receive notifications by virtue of the provisions of any PERSON applicable in connection with NORP - Cypriot property and to be present at local enquiries and negotiations concerning such property .
( d ) To administer the Fund of NORP - Cypriot properties which is established by virtue of LAW of this PERSON ;

Provided that in the case of immovable property , the Custodian , in the exercise of his functions by virtue of this section , can not take actions as a result of which after the termination of the operation of this Law–

( i ) The owner would be other than the owner at the date of entry into force of the present PERSON , except in exceptional cases in which this would be beneficial for the owner or necessary in the public interest ; or

( ii ) the right of the owner concerning the property would be in any way restricted or charged more than what would be absolutely necessary or beneficial for the property or the owner or necessary in the public interest ; ... ”

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL requires the Custodian , in administering the ORG properties and in exercising his functions by virtue of LAW , to look after the needs of refugees and at the same time serve the interests of the owners of the said properties on the basis of “ prescribed criteria ” .

CARDINAL . The plaintiffs , NORP living in GPE since DATE , were owners of CARDINAL plots of land and a house . In DATE refugee housing was built on CARDINAL of the plots ; the other CARDINAL plots and the house were granted to refugees for temporary use . The plaintiffs filed a civil action before ORG seeking eviction orders , rents as from DATE of trespass and exemplary damages .

CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG found that the respondent had committed trespass . It held that Law CARDINAL/CARDINAL was not applicable to the case as no evidence had been put before it establishing that the plaintiffs had abandoned their property as a result of the NORP invasion of DATE . The court dismissed the GPE claim for exemplary damages and awarded them ordinary damages for trespass , noting that they had , during the proceedings , withdrawn their application for return of the house . The Attorney - General appealed the judgment .

CARDINAL . Handing down its judgment , ORG set aside the findings of the first - instance court concerning the non - applicability of LAW to the case . Relying on the definition of “ NORP - Cypriot ” in section QUANTITY of the PERSON ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , the court concluded that the definition of “ abandoned property ” had been specified by the legislator as the property of a NORP who did not have his ordinary residence in the areas controlled by the Republic . The meaning of the term “ abandoned properties ” was therefore unambiguous and LAW applied in the PERSON case .

CARDINAL . ORG ordered that the case be sent back to ORG for retrial to determine the amount of compensation from the date of trespass as ascertained by the first instance court until DATE of entry into force of Law CARDINAL/CARDINAL on DATE and to determine whether the relevant provisions of LAW were constitutional . It noted that if the answer to the latter question was positive then the claim for damages for the period after DATE would have to be dismissed ; if negative , then damages would have to be assessed for the period after DATE .
CARDINAL . The case was eventually settled at the retrial stage and the constitutionality issue was therefore not determined .

CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG rejected the argument that Law CARDINAL/CARDINAL infringed LAW by requisitioning property indefinitely , noting that the law did not provide for requisition or acquisition but administration , and for a temporary period only .

CARDINAL . The Custodian initiated a civil action for possession of certain properties in accordance with LAW . The defendants submitted that they were in possession of the relevant properties in accordance with their agreement with the ORG ( a public benefit foundation ) and that ORG properties were excluded from the application of the PERSON .

CARDINAL . On DATE , in an interim judgment , ORG decided that properties owned by the ORG were not excluded from LAW . It considered that LAW was contrary to LAW but that it could be justified on the basis of the doctrine of necessity for the administration and protection of the abandoned TurkishCypriot property . The defendants appealed .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the appeal . It held that following the NORP invasion and occupation , the ORG was entitled to take measures which entailed limitation or even deprivation of the rights and liberties set out in LAW . Law CARDINAL/CARDINAL introduced measures to allow the ORG to meet the needs that arose due to the NORP invasion and , the court concluded , the measures were both necessary and proportionate .

CARDINAL . NORP The plaintiff , a NORP , was the owner of a property in the district of GPE since DATE . Following the enactment of LAW , his property was vested in the Custodian and used by CARDINAL NORP Cypriots . In DATE , the plaintiff moved from the occupied area of GPE to the government - controlled area and requested that his house be returned to him . His request was dismissed on the ground that as a result of the NORP invasion of DATE , all NORP - Cypriot properties had been vested in the Custodian until final settlement of the NORP problem .

CARDINAL . The plaintiff lodged a recourse against this decision with ORG under Article CARDINAL of the LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . He contended , inter alia , that he was entitled to recover his property as he resided in the government - controlled area , relying on section CARDINAL of the PERSON ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . The Attorney General argued that “ residence ” was determined on DATE the PERSON entered into force and not at any subsequent time so that from the moment the Custodian took over the administration of NORP - Cypriot property , such administration would continue as long as the PERSON was in force .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the ORG ’s interpretation of LAW , finding that such an interpretation would constitute an illogical , unjustifiable and excessive limitation of the fundamental constitutional right to property . It referred to the preamble of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) and held that :

“ ... the Legislator also decided , as it appears from the definition of the term ‘ NORP - Cypriot’ , as his criterion , that only in the case where the owners of the properties in question are not resident in the areas controlled by the Republic is their protection necessary , evidently as those NORP properties whose owners live in the areas controlled by the Republic do not need such protection , thus establishing a criterion which does not apply generally to NORP - Cypriots en masse but specifically to each owner . The ordinary residence of the specific owner in the areas controlled by the Republic , as the criterion of the same Legislator , puts the said specific properties on the same footing as all the other properties there and rules out the intervention or further intervention of the Custodian in their protection and administration . As things are , it does not matter whether the specific owner acquired his ordinary residence in the areas controlled by the Republic before or after CARDINAL.CARDINAL.CARDINAL and whether he returns to his ordinary residence there and seeks to live in his own house . In such a case , the criterion of the PERSON itself excludes the property from the administration of the Custodian . And , furthermore , it is certainly not only , to avoid referring to elementary human logic , the normal rules of interpretation which dictate this view but also the fundamental principles of interpretation which require the interpretation of the laws to be compatible with constitutional rights and to be analogously restrictive . If the PERSON were to be interpreted otherwise so as to cover the continuation of the administration of NORP - Cypriot property after the reestablishment of the ordinary residence of the owner in the areas controlled by the Republic , in all probability it would constitute an unjustified and excessive , even as regards the necessity expressly stated in the PERSON as justifying this , restriction of the fundamental constitutional right to property . This approach also arises from the jurisprudence of the ORG as regards the validity of the principle of proportionality , as an objective and reasonable criterion , concerning the restrictions which may be placed on the basis of discrimination in violation of LAW ( which is reflected in LAW ) . It is sufficient for me to refer to a very recent decision in the case of PERSON v GPE , CARDINAL , CARDINAL . ”
CARDINAL . Accordingly , ORG upheld the recourse and annulled the decision in question .
CARDINAL . The Attorney General filed an appeal against the judgment but withdrew this on DATE . The plaintiff ’s property was returned to him on DATE .

CARDINAL . The plaintiff , a NORP , was appointed administrator of the estate of his deceased father , who owned a CARDINAL share of a plot of land in the district of GPE which had vested in the Custodian . It reaffirmed the need to protect the abandoned properties of NORP and to help displaced NORP Cypriots who had lost their property that had been created following the NORP occupation . NORP Cypriots were not deprived of their property as they continued to be the owners , notwithstanding the fact that during the abnormal situation , the administration of the properties was vested in the Custodian . The court further considered that the fact that the abnormal situation had continued for so many years did not affect the temporary nature of the PERSON as it did not intend to impose permanent limitations or to deprive the lawful owners of their rights . The measures adopted were absolutely necessary and proportionate to the situation which had to be faced .

“ LAW protocol , after recognising the right of every natural or legal person to peaceful enjoyment of his property , refers to the exceptions , to set aside the right for public interest purposes under conditions provided for by the law and by the general principles of public international law . The protection afforded by LAW does not take away the right of the state to enact such laws as it considers to be necessary for controlling the use of property in accordance with the general interest ...

The exception of LAW exists in the present case . LAW was mandated for reasons of public interest which are obvious . On the contrary in GPE ’s case the deprivation of the rights of Ms. PERSON was made without any legal basis and of course without the existence of any law . Let us not forget that the occupied part of GPE does not constitute a state recognised by the international community . Moreover , in the case of LAW ownership remains with the NORP - Cypriot owners and the Custodian simply has the responsibility and competence to administer the property until the end of the abnormal situation ... ”
